title: Exam Scores | 2 of 2
question_text:

These side-by-side stemplots represent the scores on the final exam for a statistics teacher’s $1^\text{st}$ period class $(n = 29)$ on the left and $5^\text{th}$ period class $(n = 22)$ on the right. The scores are raw scores, out of a possible $100\text{ points}$.
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: If the two sets of data were combined into one set, the new distribution would be nearly normal.
If the data for the two groups were combined, the overall mean would be the average of the means of each group.

If the data for the two groups were combined, the range would be unchanged from that of 1st
period.
The two groups have similar standard deviations.
The two groups have similar skewness in their distributions.

solution:
The range for 1st
period is 95−49=46
. The range for the combined data will still be 46
, because the lowest value for 5th
period is greater than the lowest value for 1st
period, and the highest value for 5th
period is equal to the highest value for 1st
period.

Thus, Choice 'C' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the combined distribution would have an even higher frequency of values in the 80′s
and 90s
, with no tapering off above the 90′s
.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; with unequal sample sizes, one would have to calculate a weighted mean to calculate the combined mean. If the periods were the same size, however, this answer would have been correct.
